utterances: And so we went backstage to meet Dinah.
And Dinah dared me to sing.
She was really being facetious with me.
She leaned over and she said, hi, I'm Dinah Washington and I'm a singer.
And everybody in the dressing room laughed and I said, well, I'm Patti Austin and I'm a singer too.
And everybody just kind of looked at me like Scooby Doo, particularly my parents who were like what is she doing?
And Dinah said, oh really?
Well, if you're a singer, then you're going to go out and you're going to sing on the next show.
And I said, okay.
And totally fearless and precautious, and her musical director walked by the door and she stopped him and said, this is Patti Austin and she's a singer and she's going to sing on the next show.
And he leaned over and he continued being facetious, and said, what are you going to sing?
I said, Teach Me Tonight.
So everybody started laughing and he said, yeah, what key do you sing it in?
And I said, B-flat.
Oh my.
Because at that time I knew more about music than I knew about reading words.

Because I would sit with my dad when he would practice for hours and he would show me what every note meant, and he'd put a metronome on and he'd make me keep time with the metronome and he'd play notes and have me sing them back.

And so Dinah calls me onstage and I go out to sing the song and the band starts playing the intro, and the musical director forgot to tell them that I was doing it in a different key and so I stopped them.
I said, you guys are in the wrong key.
And the audience went wild.
Oh, gosh.

And they started the song up again in the right key and I sang the song in the right key, and everybody loved it and I ran off the stage and into the arms of Sammy Davis Jr., who was waiting on his knees.
So I thought he was actually my height.
And I ran to him, and he almost was my height actually at that time.
And he grabbed me and picked me up and said, oh my God, you've got to do my show next week.
And he took me out into the hallway off the wings of the theatre and went up to my parents and said, can she do my show next week?
(Soundbite of ""Swanee"")
So that's how I got started in showbiz.
(Singing) Swanee, how I love you.
How I love you, my dear old Swanee...
I see, OK, so that makes a difference.
We have since found personal documents bearing the names of three of those four men close to the seats of three of the explosions.
As regard to the man who was reported missing, some of his property was found on the Route 30 bus in Tavistock Square.

Property in the name of a second man was found at the scene of the Aldgate bomb, and in relation to a third man, property in his name was found at the scene of both the Aldgate and the Edgware Road bombs.
We also have very strong forensic and other evidence that it is very likely one of the men from West Yorkshire died in the explosion at Aldgate.
This, of course, is subject to formal confirmation by the coroner.
Deputy Assistant Commissioner Peter Clarke of London's Metropolitan Police.
Joining us now from Bush House in London is NPR's Jim Zarroli.
Very good of you to be with us, Jim.
Thank you, Neal.
Let's go over a bit of what we heard, Jim.
First, the investigation focuses on these four men.
What do we know about them, who they are, where they're from?
Well, we don't know a lot about them individually at this point.
We know that three of them are from the city of Leeds in West Yorkshire which is about three hours north of London by train.
It's a city and a region with a large Muslim population, a lot of Pakistanis, a lot of people from South Asia.
We don't know much about where the fourth person was from.
We don't know anything about that.
The BBC is reporting that the men were born and raised in Britain, but that hasn't been confirmed.
We know that according to the police they came down early on the morning of July 7th, and after the explosions, one of them was reported missing by his family.
Is it fair to leap to the conclusion perhaps that these four men were in Leeds and drove to the train and then took the train to London?
Well, the train station is in Luton.
I believe that's the one you're referring to, and that is--it's fairly close to London...
Thirty miles out.
...about 30 miles north of London.
So it would have been hard for them to drive to that.
Yet there was a car there that is subject of investigation, and, indeed, I think it was a controlled explosion there.
Right.
Yes, the police have basically told us that they carried out a controlled explosion at a car.
They thought the car was connected to one of the men involved in the attacks and they shut down the parking garage where it was and carried out a controlled explosion.
They haven't told us much more than that, why they were interested in this, you know, why they carried out an explosion.
Then another controlled explosion.
They said they executed six search warrants in Leeds, including the home addresses of three of the men.
Do we know what the other three addresses were?
No, we don't.
As you said, this was at--the explosion there was carried out at the homes of one of the men.
The house was not occupied at the time.
This is in the neighborhood of Burley which is in Leeds, again an area with a heavy Muslim population.
It's what you would call a sort of modest row house.
They went there very early this morning and basically carried out a controlled explosion at the door of the house.
They also went into the homes of some of the other men.
They ended up arresting one man in West Yorkshire.
We have no idea why.
He's being brought to London.
And have we any word on what they may have found if anything in any of those places where they've searched?
No. They've told us very little about that.
They basically have 1ealed off the area and it's been difficult for us to find out much about the men involved.
The people up there have been kind of reluctant to talk so far.
Deputy Assistant Commissioner Clarke mentioned closed-circuit video surveillance tape of the four men meeting outside of King's Cross station.
Have we seen that video?
No, we have not.
There are a lot of closed-circuit TV cameras in central London.
Police have said they're sort of very slowly going through a lot of these tapes.
They have 2,500 tapes they have to look through, a lot of information, obviously.
They had people from the police force pickpocket unit looking through them.
You know, that's very slow and painstaking work.
As you said, they were able to find a key piece of evidence which is a shot of four of the men together a little before 8:30.
That was about 20 minutes before the explosions went off.
So the inference you can take is that they met there and separated, went on to different trains and that's when the explosions took place.
There is as yet very little progress on identifying those killed in the explosion.
The official death toll is still 52?
Yes, it is.
The 52 dead--they've been very slow actually identifying victims and I think some of the families have been kind of frustrated.
They've been expressing concerns about that.
As you can imagine, very difficult time for them.
The defense minister today actually appealed to families to just try to be patient, this is very difficult work, he said.
So far they've identified four of the dead.
They identified two more today.
They were 30-year-old Jamie Gordon and 28-year-old Philip Stuart Russell.
Both of them worked in the city's financial district.
It also appears now that an American is likely to be among the dead.
His name is Mike Matsushita.
He comes from the Bronx in New York.
He lived in London.
He was 37.
Very, very very familiar story there by now.
He left for work Thursday morning.
I have read that he was a tour guide.
Left for work Thursday morning, never was heard from again.
His death has not been confirmed, but a family spokesman has said that his family has basically been told more or less not to expect him to be alive at this point.
Now this investigation, which was seemingly stalled for quite some time, is now being described as fast-moving.
Any indication at all of where it goes next?
Well, we don't quite know what that means yet.
Right.
Yet obviously in the immediate aftermath, there has been a rather gentle questioning thus far from the opposition in Parliament.
Well, no. I mean, obviously they have to find out more about these men, about what kind of ties they may have had to other groups, you know, as much information about them individually as possible.
The police say they're conducting a complex and intensive investigation that's moving at great speed.
They are also saying it's really just getting under way, but this today, what happened, is obviously just a huge breakthrough.
A few days ago the police were telling us they didn't know whether these attacks were conducted by suicide bombers or just planted on the bus and on the subway cars.
They said they had no evidence one way or another.
Now they've more or less established that at least one of the bombers has died and they have some pretty good evidence that some of the others may have as well.
NPR's Jim Zarroli, thanks very much.
You're welcome, Neal.
NPR's Jim Zarroli joined us from Bush House in London.
And with us now by phone is Peter Bergen.
He's the author of ""Holy War, Inc.,"" one of the few people who's ever interviewed Osama bin Laden and now a fellow at the New America Foundation here in Washington, DC.
Peter, good to have you back on the program.
Hi, Neal.
What do you make of this breakthrough in the investigation, particularly the word that at least three of these four men are from Leeds in northern England, apparently British born and raised?
Well, I mean, not surprising entirely.
We've seen--it now appears that one of these men may have engaged in a suicide attack judging from what the police are saying.
It's not the first time British citizens have engaged in suicide attacks.
They've done it outside the country in Israel two years ago.
Two second-generation British middle-class guys went into a busy jazz club near the US Embassy in Tel Aviv, and one of them blew themselves up.
And I think that that was a harbinger of some things to come, including obviously this attack in London on Thursday.
And we've also seen British citizens attempting to bring down US airliners.
Richard Reid, the so-called shoe bomber, was British.
The fact that it's homegrown is not entirely surprising.
Perhaps they were also in touch with people from outside.

Certainly if they are perhaps second-generation or first-generation South Asian immigrants to the United Kingdom, Pakistanis perhaps or Indian Muslims by descent, that would not be entirely surprising, and certainly given the fact that they're living in Leeds in the north of England is a place where a number of Muslim immigrants have settled and that would lead me in that direction, although we don't have names yet.

We'll talk more with Peter Bergen about the investigation and what it suggests about the attacks last week in London, and we'll also find out more about the city of Leeds when we come back from a short break.
If you'd like to join the conversation, our number is (800) 989-8255.
E-mail us at totn@npr.org.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
